Clapeyron equation explains this! Pressure and temperature phase diagrams too, albeit more qualitatively. As pressure increases, the melting point decreases in this case. The high e string is important as it is the thinnest while gravitational force of the bottles is the same, thus pressure is the highest (P=F/A). Then the melting point changes, making it “cut through” more quickly than it just melting through. Since the pressure is relieved once the string goes through, it refreezes. And voila! Although pressure is a factor in melting the ice here, the majority of the melting is occurring by the transfer of ambient heat through the string. This phenomenon is generally known as string theory.

A more accurate experiment would have the whole thing done in a freezer set to 32F, with all components at the same temperature.

Also the refreezing here is not primarily due to pressure relief. It is a majority function of the dissipation of the heat of the liquid water into the larger block volume. The experiment done under the same conditions with a small ice cube would have very different results.

It’s not technically the pressure itself that’s melting the Ice. The string itself is not moving. It has no action so not energy is being used on it. However the two weights pull the string downward with the help of gravity and the additional weight. If what I took from TheActionLab is correct then that is newly applied energy to do nothing. Just sit there. But this is causing friction with the contact of the ice which is transferred into heat “melting” the ice. It’s more about the friction FROM the pressure. Not pressure itself. If we compacted the ice tighter and tighter and tighter while excluding friction the Ice won’t melt. It’ll crumble as the volume of the ice has no where to go but inside itself. But if you applied friction to this example, the ice would melt as the friction coming from all angles is being transferred into heat. Pressure does not melt. Friction does. Diamonds for example are creating by applied immense pressure which causes heat to change carbon molecule structures. Why ground layers are fused together due to pressure surrounding all sides. Now the refreezing is just ice making contact with colder Ice. There’s more colder Ice than warm ice so the balance is to freeze again. You can combine metals in a similar way known as cold welding. Two metals can be combined with enough pressure. Two Aluminum foil sheets can be combined together into one sheet.  The reason why we can’t do it in our average home is because there is an oxygen layer on both the sheets. (If  someone had a vacuum chamber in their home then it can be plausible to combine the layers)This impacts the molecules of the metals retracting the attraction they have towards each other. It’s like trying to stick something on a wet wall. You gotta dry before you stick something. I would recommend watching TheActionLab. He explains everything and finds a deeper understanding of what’s going on. The type of welding we see here is not cold welding. But actually regular welding. you melt super hot metal and apply it to either multiple or singular pieces of metal. The melted metal interacts with the colder medal. If done incorrectly you get what is known as cold shuts. When the the same molecule (doesn’t have to be the same but is usually common in inexperienced welders) is in two different temperatures that creates too much stress on the metal and cracks. Pressure did not melt the ice. Friction did.

That's not just pressure. This is very misleading. In fact, increasing pressure alone would actually induce freezing. This has more to do with crack propagation (induced by high local stress).

My guesstimate as to the refreezing is that it simply caused by the surrounding ice having low enough energy state to absorb enough energy to freeze any local water that has been liquified during the process of crack propagation, which could only occur if the temperature of the room is above 0°C.

This is coming from what I've learned from engineering classes relevant to the situation - mechanical behavior of materials and thermodynamics. And I can definitely say that pressure alone is not the cause of this phenomenon.

This is a unique characteristic of the water coming out from its hydrogen bond, which causes H2O molecules to form a kind of hexagonal shape when it is in solid-state. This makes the solid state of H2O, the ice, less dense than the liquid state of H2O, the water, unlike other materials because there is vacant space inside the hexagon of the frozen H2O; general material's density is higher when it is in solid state. (if the ice were more dense than water, there would be no iceberg floating around the two polar regions).
And, as pressure increases, density also increases, regardless of one's state: solid, liquid, and gas. Same for the water. As pressure is exerted on the ice, its density also increases, and the most dense condition of H2O is achieved when it is in liquid state, the water (the pressure breaks the hexagonal shape of H2O).

the proper way to do this experiment. Put EVERYTHING in a 0 C chamber. wait for the wire to get to 0. THEN place the wire on the ice. The thing here is metal has a much higher thermal conductivity than water/ice. That means it absorbs and transfers heat far faster than the ice. The experiment seems flawed to me. I don't think it is the pressure that melts the ice, I think it is the metal from the guitar cord. Metal is a very good conductor of heat, which means when the ice cools the metal cord, heat from the environment is conducted through the wire to the coldest part (in the ice) which melts it. The reason the ice doesn't break in two is that as soon as the wire starts slipping through, the water freezes again due to the block of ice (as water is also a good conductor of heat). This experiment doesn't really have to do with pressure; just the conductivity of metal. The same experiment can be carried out by placing a copper penny on a piece of ice, it would also melt the ice even though there is no significant pressure.

Regelation, i.e., ice melts under compression and freezes again when the compression is relieved, remains puzzling since 1850 when Faraday firstly noted this phenomenon. Recent progress [Sun, et al., J Phys Chem Lett 2013. 4: 3238 and Chem Sci 2012. 3: 1455] inspired us to resolve this anomaly from the perspective of hydrogen bond (O:H-O) recoverability and water quasi-solid phase boundary dispersion. Compression shortens the length dL, increases the energy EL and phonon-frequency L of the O:H nonbond whereas the H-O bond responses oppositely to compression. O:H-O bond recovers its original state completely along its potential paths once the pressure is removed and oxygen atom finds bonding partners to retain its sp3-orbital hybridization once the O:H nonbond breaks. Theoretical reproduction of observations confirmed that the Ex and x reversible relaxation modulates, respectively, the integral and Debye temperature of the respective specific heat x(T) (x = L and H for the O:H and H-O bond) whose superposition creates retractable quasi-solid phase boundaries or critical temperatures for phase transition. Such memory and recoverability of O:H-O bond may provide possible mechanism for damage recovery of living cells.

I think this theory of regelation is slightly misleading and easily misconstrued considering that it is nearly universal that an increasing pressure decreases a substance's freezing point. The exception of water is due to the fact that ice is less dense than liquid water, due to the lattice configuration specific to water. The theory of regelation is a phenomenon that only occurs for such substances.

If you look at the phase envelope of water, you can see that increasing pressure up to the triple point (the condition at which a substance can exist as either gas, liquid, our solid) at 0.006 atm, the freezing point (technically called deposition in this case, or gas to solid) in fact increases until it reaches the triple point of 0.1 C. Obviously, this window is very small and hardly measurable in the real world. But once that triple point is exceeded in pressure, assuming the temperature of the body stays constant, the freezing temperature (or melting temperature in this case) begins to decrease, as the pressure exerted on the solid interface exceeds the strength of the solid lattice. This is why it takes a relatively significant pressure to actually observe this.

Another thing to note is the added effect of using wire with high thermal conductivity, allowing significantly more heat transfer between the surrounding air and the point of contact than if say, a nylon high E string was used for this experiment. Transversely, I imagine you would see a significantly faster effect using copper wire. It would be interesting to see the three conditions side by side to take a look at how much heat transfer is effecting the situation. You could probably determine this if you had accurate measurements of the surrounding temperature and pressure, calculated the effective pressure exerted by the wire, and compared the rate of melting to the phase envelope and what you would expect to see assuming no heat transfer. But that would be way too much work and who would actually want to do that.. Transport Phenomena professors, eat this up.

Now, after the pressure has been alleviated by way of the ice melting, P will return to normal atmospheric pressure. This will allow Temperature to go back down below 0C, resolidifying.

I only have one correction: the term "regelation" is inappropriate here, because ice is a crystal not a gel. A gel is a continuous matrix (usually made of a crosslinked polymer), wherein the (liquid) solvent is filling the space around the matrix forming component, such as the polymer network chains. 
in the case of ice, the phenomenon you showed in this video is a recrystallization process.

Most solids are more dense then the liquid state of the same material. When you apply pressure, thermodynamics favors the more dense state, the solid.

Ice, because it has a really weird crystal structure, is less dense then water and so applying pressure causes it to melt. Again, thermodynamics tells us that the higher pressure favors the more dense state, meaning the water.

So, you're saying that pressure can't melt ice? I'm sorry to upset you, but that's false. Have you ever studied chemistry in school? If you have, then you would have probably seen the phase diagram for water and studied LeChatelier's principle, which states that a substance at equilibrium experiences a change in one of the factors influencing it, then the equilibrium will shift to counteract the imposed change. Since water is more dense in liquid form, it will melt at higher pressure.

You'd be surprised!

Chemistry says that as pressure is applied to the solid water, equilibrium shifts to favour the liquid form more. Go look at a triple point graph of water, and look at what pressure does to it! Water is an exception to the general rule, though; this wouldn't work too well on most substances. 

Physics says that as more pressure is applied to the water, it wants to become more dense. And because water is more dense than ice, it melts!

It's some crazy stuff, phase changes.

It's the pressure.  The wire he used only has a cross section of about 1/100,000th of a square meter on the ice (figuring 5cm long x 0.3mm across), and it's supporting ~2kg of water - that's ~13 atmospheres (~1.3MPa.)  It's more than enough to lower the melting point of ice and allow it to liquefy without heating. Also, thermal conductivity might explain why the ice would melt at the edges, but if that were the case the middle of the ice would never melt.  The wire would just be too cold.

A/C works on the refrigeration cycle idea, like fridges. Refrigerant vapor is pressurized by a compressor and undergoes a phase change, vapor to liquid. As a result, the difference in energy of motion between fast vapor molecules and slow liquid molecules is released where this is happening, the A/C unit (why hot air comes out). If the process is reversed, the refrigerant needs energy to vaporize. Energy it gets from the air it cools. Then back to the compressor it goes for another round.

The ice isn't melting due to the thermal conductivity of the copper, but due to the fact that water is more dense as a fluid. When pressure is applied, the ice tries to compensate for it by becoming more dense, which it can only do when it turns into a liquid. This is unique to water and a few other materials. Normally, when pressure is added to a liquid it will turn into a solid. This is why the earth has a solid iron core even though there is plenty of heat to melt the iron. Aka la chateliers

Cold water expands. Hot water doesn't.
So when you freeze cold water, there is more volume taken up by it. Think of it as there being "more water to freeze". So since the difference in the amount of space it takes up ends up being more significant than the temperature difference, the cold water takes longer. Of course this only works when you have the same amount of water (same weight) so that the cold water expands and takes up more space.

Freeze the water slowly from the bottom and you allow the gasses in the solution to escape. When you make ice cubes in your freezer, you're freezing the ice from all sides, which is why the gasses create bubbles in the middle of the cube - they stay in solution until freezing and the last bit to freeze in a cube is in the middle.

No, the wire was at the same (or close to) the temperature of the ice. It's because of pressure. I did it outside this February by -5°C and after 17 hours, the wire had just started to go half a millimetre into the ice on the edges but was still free on top.

When I brought the apparatus inside, the (metal) wire crossed the block in 20 minutes.

I drove a long way to the outskirts of Sydney and got ice from an ice sculptor - they freeze their own ice in freezers that keep the water moving on top. This means that instead of freezing the top and edges inwards, trapping the air, it freezes from the bottom up and remains clear.

Nice demo: thanks. We did this experiment at the Royal Society in London a few years ago, but we put the whole thing in a glass-fronted freezer - like those used in shops. My calculation is that 10 atmospheres pressure lowers the melting temperature by only 0.1 degrees Celsius. So depending on the temperature of the block of ice in your experiment I think you may be observing a combination of effects. Pressure melting aided by thermal melting near the edges.

Maybe if you did it in a freezer then it would be more convincing. There won't be any skeptics thinking "not it's not, it's to do with the temperature difference between the ice and and the room derp derp derp".
